instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: [DEAD]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No turn on, <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> I believe
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8V6
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3V44
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3V3
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3V3


<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 61mV
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V


<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0V -> 0.5 Ohms to ground

Removed <RESISTOR>R7310</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7320</RESISTOR> tested each pad.
<RESISTOR>R7320</RESISTOR> Pad 2 (<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>) / <RESISTOR>R7310</RESISTOR> Pad 1 (<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>) = 0.5 Ohms to ground.
Injected 1V but it only pulls ~ 1A and voltage not pulled to 0 and maintains at 1V. Clearly, nothing is going to get hot...... Is it possible CPU or bad cap or am I completely wrong?

What should I do please?

threads.title: [DEAD]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No turn on, <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> I believe
threads.message: First off, was this liquid and where?

threads.title: [DEAD]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No turn on, <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> I believe
threads.message:
Yes liquid damage around <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, Y1915, <CHIP>U3540</CHIP>.

L7310, L7320 look a little brown

Board had been cleaned before it was sent.

threads.title: [DEAD]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No turn on, <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> I believe
threads.message: Replace <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and check resistors in data lines and the traces to <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.

threads.title: [DEAD]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No turn on, <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> I believe
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 6947"]Replace <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and check resistors in data lines and the traces to <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.[/QUOTE]

No change. R values good, traces good.

Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0.5Ohms.

threads.title: [DEAD]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No turn on, <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> I believe
threads.message: Measured on a good board here CPU Vcore is about 140 Ohms. I think your CPU is cooked.

threads.title: [DEAD]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No turn on, <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> I believe
threads.message:
I thought you may say that. Good board most certainly NOT 0.5ohms......

A moment of silence for my dead CPU please.
